question1.question:
An Einstein Analytics consultant is working on a dataset where row-level security needs to be implemented.
How can the user accomplish this?
question1.option1text: Define a security predicate, turn on sharing inheritance, or do both.
question1.option1textexplanation: Correct. To restrict access to records, you can implement row-level security on a dataset when you use sharing inheritance and security predicates.
question1.option2text: Enable field-level security on a dataset.
question1.option2textexplanation: Incorrect. Field-level security does not implement row-level security on a dataset.
question1.option3text: Adjust the user’s profile to determine row-level security on a dataset.
question1.option3textexplanation: Incorrect. Adjusting the user’s profile affects all users with that profile and does not determine row-level security on a dataset.
question1.option4text: Create a permission set to enable row-level sharing on a dataset.
question1.option4textexplanation: Incorrect. Permission sets do not enable row-level sharing on a dataset in Einstein Analytics.

question2.question:
An Einstein Analytics consultant wants to restrict row-level access within the dataset to only users who own the specific records.
How can a user achieve this through a security predicate?
question2.option1textexplanation: Incorrect. Record.Id is not the correct field to use.
question2.option2textexplanation: Incorrect. UserId is not the correct field to use.
question2.option3textexplanation: Correct. OwnerId refers to the dataset column that contains the user ID of the owner of the record. While $User.Id refers to the Id column of the User object.
question2.option4textexplanation: Incorrect. Role.Id is not the correct field to use.
